seg.seg: solicit you venerable one [as] upādhyāya. (May you venerable one be my upādhyāya.) With (you) venerable one [as] upādhyāya I will be ordained. This
[must be] spoken three [times]. Are you able [to be the] upādhyāya for N.N.? ([Yes,] I am able!) Are you, Vimalayaśa, able [to be] the instructor [anuśāsaka] for Yaśakāma?
[Yes,] (I) am able! Thereupon the one who shall be instructor shall lead the novice-to-be-ordained out of earshot, [but] let him stand within eyeshot.
Thereupon the one who shall be instructor shall return, enter [and] take his seat [again]. Thereupon the karmavācaka shall
speak exactly the[se] words in Indic: Let the venerable communi(ty hear!) Who, desiring the ordination of N.N. is (able) [to be] instructor,
to instruct N.N.? (Thereupon) the one who shall be (instructor) shall declare [his] readiness. Thereupon again the karmavācaka
shall say exactly these words in Indic to (the community): Let the venerable community hear! One desiring the ordination of N.N. is able to
instruct N.N. If the present moment suits the community and [if it is] the will of the community, that the community appoints N.N. [as] instructor
who shall instruct N.N., [then] this [is] the proposition: (Let) the venerable community (hear)! This Yaśakāma [i.e. Vimalayaśa], supporter of the ordination of Yaśa[kāma]
is able to instruct this Vimalayaśa [i.e. Yaśakāma]. (The community) appoints (Vimalayaśa [as] instruct)or who will instruct Yaśakāma.

p.note: The supplementation and commentaries follow 17, 134.
According to : iv-v this ms. comes either from Qizil or from Tumšuq.

This leaf is preserved almost in full width, with only a smal strip, about 0.5-1 cm high, missing in the centre. The left half consists of 3 pieces and is about 13 cm wide. The right half, consisting of 2 pieces, is about 16 cm wide. To the right of the string hole lines 1-2 are missing over a stretch of 9 and 4 cm respectively.

The original ms. was 29 cm wide and 5.6 cm high, with the string hole 6.5 cm from the left margin. It was written by at least three hands: scribe 1, a beautiful, delicate script, from leaf 1 to 11 a1; scribe 2, distinguished by a number of orthographical idiosyncrasies/errors, from leaf 11 a1 to and including 19; scribe 3 from leaf 20 to end. The final leaves A and B and may have been written either by scribe 2 or a fourth hand. Cf. : v, 2, 4
The leaf is in hand 2.
śaulasontä for śaulasont; śaulasotsa for śaulasontsa; upādhyāyetsa for upadhyāyentsa; wasanpāt for wasaṃpāt.
The last word before the gap can probably be supplemented to twe. upadhyāyetsa sic! for upādhyāyeṃtsa.
The gap contains about 10 akṣaras.
See : b5 and commentary.
weṣṣäle for weṣṣälle.
lkalyñe for lkālñe.
utsahāma should be corrected to utsahāmi. anuh·ke sic! to be corrected to anuśāsake. lkalyñe sic! for lkālyñe.

anu(śā)sake nesalyepi wasaṃ(n)pāt yamalye ṣanmireṃ ... aśalle ... stamäṣṣale: this is an impersonal gerundive construction with a dependent oblique case. The agent noun is in the genitive. On such constructions cf. 22ff.
On tumeṃ ... klyauṣalye ikemeṃ pkante aśalle lkalyñe ikene stamäṣṣale cf. Bhī 15 a5f. tataḥ paścāc chravaṇopavicāraṃ vijahayya darśanopavicāre ... (sthā)payitavyā.
stamäṣṣale for stamäṣṣälle; pästä for päst; yänmaṣṣäle for yänmaṣṣälle; ṣmale for ṣmalle; karmapāyä for karmapāy; weṣeñcatse for weṣṣeñcantse.
stamäṣṣale sic! for stamäṣṣäle.
yentukäñe for yentukäññe; weṣle for weṣṣälle.

yentukäñe is an adjectival derivation of yentuke ‘Indian’. yentukäñe pele ‘in Indic’ [lit. ‘in an Indian/Indic way’] belongs with the groups of words used adverbially which are very close to pseudo-bahuvrīhis: cf. e.g. b3 ñäkciṃ pal ‘in a heavenly manner, of the heavenly kind’, b4 ṣeme pälsko päklyauṣso ‘Listen attentively (lit. with a unified mind)!’. On this matter cf. 189f. yentuke is a very early loan from Iranian. On its significance in the study of Iranian-Tocharian exchange of vocabulary, cf. : xviiiff.
yamaṣäle for yamaṣṣälle; karmavācaketse for karmavācakentse.
yeṃtukäñe for yentukäññe; sāṅkäścä for sāṅkäśc; weṣäle for weṣṣälle.
toyk\k sic!
On yeṃtukäñe cf. commentary to line a5 above.
anuśāsaka must be corrected to anuśāsakaṃ.
